Key Arguments: The Bill threatens freedom of speech and democratic rights by allowing the government to define truth and control information.
It creates a double standard by imposing restrictions on online platforms while giving the government and mainstream media a free pass.
The Bill gives ACMA the power to subjectively define misinformation and disinformation, which could lead to abuse of power and suppression of public debate.
Tech companies could become tools of government censorship, stifling free speech and privacy.
The Bill promotes ideological conformity, suppressing dissenting voices and hindering independent thought.
Passing the Bill would breach Australia's international human rights obligations and contradict its national values.
Notable Quotes: The Bill grants the government the authority to define truth, allowing them to control and manipulate the flow of information.
The Bill paves the way for ideological conformity, suppressing dissenting voices and hindering independent thought.
Freedom of speech is a fundamental and non-negotiable human right.
